user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketShutdown:
```c
int32 OS_SocketShutdown(osal_id_t sock_id, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Confirm that "Mode" is one of the 3 acceptable values */
    BUGCHECK(Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ || Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE ||
                 Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE,
             OS_ERR_INVALID_ARGUMENT);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if (stream->socket_type == OS_SocketType_STREAM && (stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED) == 0)
        {
            /* Stream socket must not be connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(&token, Mode);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
                {
                    stream->stream_state &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
                }
                if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
                {
                    stream->stream_state &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;
                }
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketShutdown:
#define BUGCHECK(cond, errcode) if(!(cond)){BUGREPORT("\n**BUG** %s():%d:check \'%s\' FAILED --> %s\n\n",__func__,__LINE__,#cond,#errcode);returnerrcode;}
...
#define OS_ERR_INVALID_ARGUMENT (-42)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             how;

    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /* Note that when called via the shared layer,
     * the "Mode" arg has already been checked/validated. */
    if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
    {
        how = SHUT_RD;
    }
    else if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
    {
        how = SHUT_WR;
    }
    else
    {
        how = SHUT_RDWR;
    }

    if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_NONE           = 0, /**< @brief Reserved value, no effect */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ      = 1, /**< @brief Disable future reading */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE     = 2, /**< @brief Disable future writing */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE = 3  /**< @brief Disable future reading or writing */
} OS_SocketShutdownMode_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that are compile-time invariant and therefore no fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. The relevant controlling expressions in the function and related code are all dependent on runtime values, not constants:

- BUGCHECK(Mode == ...): The condition depends on the function parameter Mode, which is a runtime value passed into OS_SocketShutdown, so the controlling expression is not invariant.
- if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) and if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS): return_code is set by OS_ObjectIdGetById and other runtime functions; these are not compile-time constants.
- if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID) and else if (stream->socket_type == ... && (stream->stream_state & ...) == 0): These test fields of the runtime stream object (from OS_stream_table) and a runtime bitmask; they are not invariant.
- return_code = OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(&token, Mode); and subsequent if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS): again depends on the implementation and runtime syscall result.
- if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ) and if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE): These bitmask checks depend on the Mode argument (runtime) and are not constant at compile time.
- In OS_SocketShutdown_Impl, the if/else-if/else that selects how based on Mode depends on the Mode parameter (runtime), and the final if (shutdown(... ) == 0) depends on the system call return value (runtime).

No unconditional constant controlling expressions (e.g., if (1), while(1) used as an invariant controlling expression, or a do-while with a compile-time false controlling expression) appear in the provided code. The exceptions allowed by Rule 14.3 (infinite loops or specific do-while constant-false patterns) are not relevant because none of those constructs appear. Therefore there are no suspected violations of Rule 14.3 in the given code fragments.
